body.p: “We crossed the river at Nut Meadow Brook. The ice was nearly worn through all along there, with wave-like regularity, in oblong (round end) or thick crescent or kidney shaped holes, as if worn by the summits of waves, –like a riddle to sift a man through. These holes are hard to detect in some lights except by shaking the water. I saw some cakes of ice, ten feet across and one foot thick, lodged with one end of the top of a fence-post and some seven or eight feet in the air, the other on the bottom.”
PE 9, pg. 218 / 3 Sept 1854 – 12 May 1855 / NNPM MA 1302:24 / T vol. # XVIII / PDF # XIII
